conclusion: To solve for the magnetic induction intensity B using the given information, we need to analyze the forces acting on the coil in both scenarios (with and without the additional weight).

Initially, the coil is balanced by adjusting the weights on the right arm. This means that the torque due to the magnetic force on the coil must be equal to the torque due to the weight difference between the two pans.
The magnetic force on each side of the coil is given by F = n I L B.
Since the coil is rectangular and the magnetic field is uniform, the net magnetic force on the coil will be zero because the forces on opposite sides of the coil cancel each other out.
The torque due to the magnetic force on one side of the coil is τ_magnetic = n I L B * (L/2) = (n I L^2 B)/2.
The torque due to the weight difference is τ_weight = (m_R - m_L) g * (L/2).
Setting the torques equal gives n I L B = (m_R - m_L) g, leading to B = ((m_R - m_L) g)/(n I L).
When the current is reversed, the direction of the magnetic force on the coil reverses, causing the coil to rotate in the opposite direction.
The new torque due to the magnetic force is τ_magnetic' = (n I L^2 B)/2.
The new torque due to the weight difference is τ_weight' = (m_R - m_L + m) g * (L/2).
Setting the new torques equal gives n I L B = (m_R - m_L + m) g, leading to B = ((m_R - m_L + m) g)/(n I L).
Equating the two expressions for B gives (m_R - m_L) g = (m_R - m_L + m) g, simplifying to 0 = m.
Since m_R - m_L = m, we have B = ((m + m) g)/(n I L) = (2mg)/(n I L).
Thus, the magnitude of the magnetic induction intensity B is (2mg)/(n I L).
